    "for positive integers @xmath1 , we consider the ring @xmath10)$ ] of polynomial functions on the vector space of @xmath0 matrices with entries in the complex numbers .",
    "the ring @xmath11 admits an action of the group @xmath12 , and it decomposes into irreducible @xmath5representations according to cauchy s formula : @xmath13 where @xmath14 denotes the schur functor associated to a partition @xmath15 . for each @xmath15",
    ", we let @xmath16 denote the ideal in @xmath11 generated by the irreducible representation @xmath17 .",
    "every ideal @xmath18 which is preserved by the @xmath5-action is a sum of ideals @xmath16 : such ideals @xmath19 have been classified and their geometry has been studied by de concini , eisenbud and procesi in the 80s @xcite .",
    "nevertheless , their syzygies are still mysterious , and in particular the following problem remains unsolved :    describe the syzygies of the ideals @xmath16 , together with their @xmath5-equivariant structure .",
    "the goal of our paper is to solve this problem in the case when @xmath15 is a rectangular partition , which means that there exist positive integers @xmath3 such that @xmath20 and @xmath21 for @xmath22 ( alternatively , the young diagram associated to @xmath15 is the @xmath23 rectangle ) . in this case",
    "we write @xmath24 and @xmath25 .",
    "one can think of @xmath4 as the smallest @xmath5-equivariant ideal which contains the @xmath6-th powers of the @xmath7 minors of the generic matrix of indeterminates @xmath26 .",
    "what distinguishes the ideals @xmath4 among all the @xmath16 s is that they define a scheme without embedded components , so from a geometric point of view they form the simplest class of @xmath5-equivariant ideals after the reduced ( and prime ) ideals of minors . examples of ideals @xmath4 include :    * @xmath27 , the ideal generated by the @xmath7 minors of @xmath28 . * @xmath29 , the @xmath6-th power of the ideal @xmath30 of maximal minors of @xmath28 .",
    "* @xmath31 , the ideal of @xmath32 permanents of @xmath28 : here by a @xmath32 permanent of @xmath28 we mean the permanent of a @xmath32 matrix obtained by selecting @xmath6 rows and @xmath6 columns of @xmath28 , not necessarily distinct ; for instance , when @xmath33 we have : @xmath34    to state our main result , we need to introduce some notation .",
    "we write @xmath35 for the representation ring of the group @xmath5 , and for a given @xmath5-representation @xmath36 , we let @xmath37\\in rep_{{\\operatorname{gl}}}$ ] denote its class in the representation ring .",
    "we let @xmath38 denote the vector space of @xmath39-syzygies of degree @xmath40 of @xmath4 . we encode the syzygies of @xmath4 into the equivariant betti polynomial @xmath41\\cdot w^i\\cdot z^j\\in rep_{{\\operatorname{gl}}}[z , w],\\ ] ] so the variable @xmath42 keeps track of the internal degree , while @xmath43 keeps track of the homological degree .",
    "if @xmath44 are positive integers , @xmath45 is a partition with at most @xmath46 parts ( @xmath47 for @xmath48 ) and @xmath49 is a partition with parts of size at most @xmath50 ( @xmath51 ) , we construct the partition @xmath52 this is easiest to visualize in terms of young diagrams : one starts with an @xmath53 rectangle , and attach @xmath45 to the right and @xmath49 to the bottom of the rectangle . if @xmath54 , @xmath55 , @xmath56 , @xmath57 , then @xmath58{5 + 4,5 + 2,5 + 1 } * [ * ( blue)]{0,0,0,0,3,2}\\ ] ] we write @xmath59 for the conjugate partition to @xmath60 ( obtained by transposing the young diagram of @xmath60 ) and consider the polynomials @xmath61 $ ] given by @xmath62\\cdot z^{r\\cdot s + |{\\alpha}|+|{\\beta}|}\\cdot w^{|{\\alpha}|+|{\\beta}|},\\ ] ] where the sum is taken over partitions @xmath63 such that @xmath45 is contained in the @xmath64 rectangle ( @xmath65 , @xmath66 ) and @xmath49 is contained in the @xmath67 rectangle ( @xmath68 and @xmath69 ) .",
    "we also need to introduce the gauss polynomial @xmath70 $ ] , @xmath71 which is the generating function for partitions contained inside the @xmath53 rectangle .",
    "note that @xmath72 is the poincar polynomial of the grassmannian of @xmath46-dimensional subspaces of an @xmath73-dimensional vector space , and also that @xmath74 is the usual binomial coefficient .",

    "weyman @xcite .",

    "\\hline   \\end{array}\\ ] ] taking dimensions of representations ( @xmath87 , @xmath88 , @xmath89 ) , we get the usual betti table , which can be verified for instance using macaulay2 @xcite : @xmath90    the proof of our main result is based on the following two ingredients :    * joint work of the second author with akin @xcite : they introduce and study in the context of @xmath91-modules a family of linear complexes @xmath92 , whose homology consists entirely of direct sums of ideals @xmath93 .",
    "the polynomials @xmath94 introduced in ( [ eq : defhrs ] ) precisely encode the terms of these linear complexes .",
    "* the recent work of the authors on computing local cohomology with support in determinantal ideals : in @xcite we compute all the modules @xmath95 , together with their @xmath5-equivariant structure .    based on these two ingredients , our strategy is as follows .",
    "we obtain a non - minimal resolution of @xmath4 via an iterated mapping cone construction involving the linear complexes @xmath96 , @xmath97 .",
    "we then use the @xmath5-equivariance to conclude that whenever cancellations occur for some of the terms of an @xmath98 , they must in fact occur for all the terms of @xmath98 .",
    "this implies that the minimal resolution of @xmath4 is also built out of copies of @xmath96 , and it remains to determine the number of such copies , as well as their homological shifts .",
    "this is done by dualizing the minimal resolution and using the @xmath5-equivariant description of @xmath99 .",
    "we elaborate on this argument in section  [ sec : mainthm ] , after we establish some notational conventions in section  [ sec : prelim ] , and collect some preliminary results on functoriality of syzygies , on the complexes @xmath98 , and on the computation of @xmath100 modules .",
    "if @xmath101 is a complex vector space of dimension @xmath102 , a choice of basis determines an isomorphism between @xmath103 and the group @xmath104 of @xmath105 invertible matrices .",
    "we will refer to @xmath106tuples @xmath107 as weights of the corresponding maximal torus of diagonal matrices .",
    "we say that @xmath15 is a dominant weight if @xmath108 .",
    "irreducible representations of @xmath103 are in one - to - one correspondence with dominant weights @xmath15 .",
    "we denote by @xmath109 the irreducible representation associated to @xmath15 .",
    "we write @xmath110 for the total size @xmath111 of @xmath15 .",
    "when @xmath15 is a dominant weight with @xmath112 , we say that @xmath15 is a partition of @xmath113 .",
    "we will often represent a partition via its associated young diagram which consists of left  justified rows of boxes , with @xmath114 boxes in the @xmath39th row : for example , the young diagram associated to @xmath115 is @xmath116 note that when we re dealing with partitions we often omit the trailing zeros .",

    "we now proceed to state and prove the main result of our paper :    [ thm : main ] the equivariant betti polynomial of @xmath178 , @xmath1 , is @xmath179 where @xmath180 is as defined in ( [ eq : defhrs ] ) .",
    "we prove theorem [ thm : main ] in a few stages .",
    "we first note that by functoriality ( section  [ subsec : functoriality ] ) it is enough to prove the theorem in the case @xmath171 , which we assume for the remainder of this section .",
    "we begin by constructing a non - minimal resolution of @xmath4 :    [ prop : nonminresi ] the ideal @xmath4 has a ( not necessarily minimal ) free @xmath5-equivariant resolution over @xmath11 which is filtered by the complexes @xmath163 .",
    "we prove by descending induction on @xmath162 that @xmath181 admits a ( not necessarily minimal ) resolution @xmath182 which is filtered by complexes @xmath183 with @xmath184 .",
    "if @xmath172 then @xmath185 coincides with @xmath186 : they are both isomorphic to a free module of rank one , generated by the @xmath187-th power of the determinant of the generic @xmath105 matrix .",
    "assuming now that the result is true for the ideals @xmath181 with @xmath188 , we ll prove it for @xmath189 to finish the inductive argument . by theorem  [ thm : homologyx ] the higher homology of the linear complex @xmath190 consists of direct sums of ideals",
    "@xmath191 , @xmath188 , and @xmath192",
    ". we can therefore construct a resolution @xmath193 of @xmath194 as a mapping cone of the maps from the complexes @xmath195 , @xmath188 , to the complex @xmath190 that cancel its higher homology .",
    "let @xmath196 be a non - minimal @xmath5-equivariant resolution of the ideal @xmath4 as in proposition  [ prop : nonminresi ] .",
    "we can minimize @xmath196 by making appropriate cancellations .",
    "notice that since the generators of the free modules appearing in @xmath96 and @xmath183 do nt share isomorphic irreducible @xmath5-subrepresentations for @xmath197 , the only cancellations that can occur are between the terms in various copies of the same @xmath96 .",
    "[ lem : endxrs ] any @xmath127-equivariant degree preserving endomorphism of the linear complex @xmath198 is a multiple of the identity .",
    "let @xmath199 denote a @xmath5-equivariant degree preserving endomorphism of @xmath98 , and write @xmath200 for its component in homological degree @xmath39 . by @xmath5-equivariance and using the decomposition ( [ eq : defxrs ] ) , we have @xmath201 , where @xmath202 is the restriction of @xmath200 to the free submodule @xmath203 generated by the irreducible representation @xmath204 .",
    "such an endomorphism is necessarily a multiple of the identity . writing @xmath205 , it suffices to show that all @xmath206 are the same .",
    "we prove this by induction on @xmath207 .",
    "consider @xmath208 with @xmath209 , and consider a pair @xmath210 with @xmath211 , such that the restriction of the differential @xmath212 to @xmath213 is non - zero : such a pair exists since otherwise @xmath204 would contribute to the homology of @xmath92 , which would contradict theorem  [ thm : homologyx ] .",
    "since @xmath199 commutes with the differentials , we have a commutative diagram @xmath214^{\\partial_i } \\ar[d]_{\\cdot c_{{\\alpha},{\\beta } } } & x^{r\\times s}_{{\\overline{{\\alpha}}},{\\overline{{\\beta } } } } \\ar[d]^{\\cdot c_{{\\overline{{\\alpha}}},{\\overline{{\\beta } } } } } \\\\    x^{r\\times s}_{{\\alpha},{\\beta } } \\ar[r]^{\\partial_i } & x^{r\\times s}_{{\\overline{{\\alpha}}},{\\overline{{\\beta } } } } \\\\ } \\ ] ] since @xmath215 , it follows that @xmath216 , and we conclude by induction .    the preceding discussion implies the following    [ cor : minresiab ] the minimal resolution of @xmath4 is filtered by the complexes @xmath163 , @xmath97 .",
    "in particular , there exist polynomials @xmath217 which account for the multiplicities of the complexes @xmath96 in the minimal resolution of @xmath4 , as well as for their homological shifts , i.e. @xmath218    we are now ready to prove the main result of the paper :    it remains to calculate the polynomials @xmath217 .",
    "we fix @xmath162 and shrink @xmath106 if necessary to assume that @xmath219 ( see section  [ subsec : functoriality ] ) , so @xmath220 consists of a single free module , generated by the irreducible @xmath5-representation @xmath221 . dualizing the minimal resolution @xmath222 of @xmath4 and computing the cohomology @xmath95 of the resulting complex @xmath223 , we get    1 .",
    "each occurrence of @xmath224 in @xmath222 yields a copy of @xmath176 in @xmath95 ; 2 .",
    "the only occurrences of @xmath176 inside @xmath95 arise in this way .    to prove ( a ) , note that there are no non - zero maps going into the free module @xmath224 , so",
    "its dual @xmath225 will consists entirely of cocycles in @xmath223 . since @xmath223 is minimal",
    ", the space @xmath176 of minimal generators of @xmath226 contains no coboundaries , so ( a ) follows . if ( b ) failed , one could find a free submodule @xmath227 in @xmath223 , containing @xmath176 , where @xmath36 is an irreducible @xmath5-representation appearing as a subspace of minimal generators in some complex @xmath183 , @xmath228 .",
    "the condition @xmath229 implies that @xmath36 appears as a subrepresentation of @xmath230 .",
    "this can only happen if @xmath231 , where @xmath232 are partitions containing the @xmath233 rectangle . by ( [ eq : defllrsab ] )",
    ", @xmath36 can only occur inside @xmath224 .",
    "it follows from ( a ) and ( b ) that there is a one - to - one correspondence between occurrences of @xmath224 inside @xmath222 and those of @xmath176 inside @xmath95 , and moreover this correspondence replaces homological shifts with cohomological shifts .",
    "we get ( see ( [ eq : multsmbullet ] ) and the remark following it ) that @xmath234 this concludes the proof of theorem  [ thm : main ] .",
    "this work was initiated while we were visiting the mathematical sciences research institute , for whose hospitality we are grateful .",
    "experiments with the computer algebra software macaulay2 @xcite have provided numerous valuable insights .",
    "raicu acknowledges the support of nsf grant 1458715 .",
    "weyman acknowledges the support of the alexander von humboldt foundation and of nsf grant 0901185 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the vector space of @xmath0 complex matrices ( @xmath1 ) admits a natural action of the group @xmath2 via row and column operations . for positive integers @xmath3 , </S>",
    "<S> we consider the ideal @xmath4 defined as the smallest @xmath5equivariant ideal containing the @xmath6-th powers of the @xmath7 minors of the generic @xmath0 matrix . </S>",
    "<S> we compute the syzygies of the ideals @xmath4 for all @xmath3 , together with their @xmath5equivariant structure , generalizing earlier results of lascoux for the ideals of minors ( @xmath8 ) , and of akin  buchsbaum  </S>",
    "<S> weyman for the powers of the ideals of maximal minors ( @xmath9 ) . </S>"
  ]
}
